citation.article-title: Transfer of Kingella indologenes (Snell and Lapage 1976) to the genus Suttonella gen. nov. as Suttonella indologenes comb. nov.; transfer of Bacteroides nodosus (Beveridge 1941) to the genus Dichelobacter gen. nov. as Dichelobacter nodosus comb. nov.; and assignment of the genera Cardiobacterium, Dichelobacter, and Suttonella to Cardiobacteriaceae fam. nov. in the gamma division of Proteobacteria on the basis of 16S rRNA sequence comparisons.

p.s: Cardiobacteriaceae (Car.di.o.bac.te.ri.a´ce.ae. N. L. n. Cardiobacterium, bacterium of the heart; aceae, ending to denote a family; N.L. fem. pl. n. Cardiobacteriaceae, the family of cardiobacteria)
Straight rods that are 0.5 to 1.7 μm in diameter and 1 to 6 μm long and have rounded ends.
Cells occasionally occur in pairs, rosette clusters, or chains.
Gram negative, but there is a tendency to resist Gram decolorization.
Nonmotile as determined by normal tests, but may exhibit twitching motility and possess N-methylphenylalanine-type pilins.
Aerobic and oxidase positive except for members of the anaerobic genus Dichelobacter.
Fermentative type of chemoorganotrophic metabolism except for members of the genus Dichelobacter, which are arginine chemoorganotrophs.
Acid but not gas is produced from glucose, sucrose, maltose, mannose, and fructose in fermentative species.
H2S is produced (as determined by the lead acetate method).
No growth occurs on MacConkey agar.
The G+C content of the DNA is 45 to 60 mol%.
Species in the family possess the following rare or unique signatures in their 16s rRNAs: uracil at positions 18, 1051, and 1400 and adenine at position 917 (E. coli numbering).
The family comprises the following three genera: Cardiobacterium (the type genus), Suttonella, and Dichelobacter.
